top_comment.text:
If humans evolved then why are there still apes? If humans evolved then how 
would we have survived with our rather silly physical defenses, we lack 
claws, we have small teeth that are incapable of dealing much damage in 
most cases, and how do you suppose we would figure out things like; what is 
edible and what's not, which animals are dangerous, which animals are food, 
or what to do when winter comes? If humans evolved then why is it that we 
don't have a thick fur to survive harsh winters before we knew how to make 
fire and other such things? Now, to broaden the spectrum, if animals 
evolved from one another then why can they not reproduce among one another 
(assuming they come from common ancestors and such) as they please? If 
animals evolved then why does fossil evidence indicate otherwise in many 
circumstances? If animals evolved then why is there a beetle that's capable 
of spraying flaming liquid at enemies without burning itself by using an 
explosive, a catalyst, and an anti-catalyst? To add to the beetle topic, if 
this beetle were to evolve gradually over time as many scientists suggest 
animals did, then it would first have to develop the explosive type liquid 
over millions of years, which would leave it completely defenseless until 
then. After that happened, every time it would use the explosive, the 
beetle would die, so it would have to spend millions of years developing 
the catalyst for the explosive. After that, the explosive would fail to 
work thus leaving it defenseless again for millions of years. When it 
finally developed the anti-catalyst then it would have to spend potentially 
millions of years hardwiring the way to effectively use the weapon into 
their genetics. Point being, I don't support evolution. You can support it 
if you want, I honestly don't care (there's a first amendment for that 
reason). Just please don't broadcast it as if it's a flawless theory. 
Another thing, it is just a theory and there's a number of scientists who 
say it's extremely unlikely that something like that would happen. Have a 
blessed day, love ya brother!﻿

stomach full is uncomfortable and inefficient. Even trying to work on

top_comment.author: Nephania Black

comments.text:
You're not wrong. Let me be perfectly clear about this before I say 
anything else. Everything you've said is, by and large, fact. However, you 
seemed to have missed the point of what he was saying. 

First, he didn't say that temperature changes don't affect the body and 
make it easier for the virus to afflict someone. What he said was that the 
cold virus occurs more often during the winter because you spend more time 
inside with other people that might have it. In fact, your point only helps 
to emphasize this even more; it's the sudden change from cold to warm when 
you go inside that helps you contract the virus more easily. You also have 
a chance of getting it if you hang around a lot of people when you go 
outside, but it's generally easier for a virus to get you inside because of 
the amount of things people physically handle in their homes.

Second, he might have exaggerated a bit by mentioning the gold medal, but 
he did cover the fact that you shouldn't go for a long or intense session 
of swimming after a meal. While it's fair to criticize him for not being a 
bit more clear about this, it should also be easy to follow his train of 
thought and assume that it's not going to cause you much physical 
discomfort to get in a pool and just chill after a big meal. Because it 
won't. As a lazy guy who likes to just sit in his pool after a good 
barbecue on a nice summer day, I can attest to this fact.

My sister sleep talks a LOT and I eventually got used to hearing her talk 
on the other side of my wall at night. Well, one night it was late and my 
sister had been asleep for well over two hours. I was sitting at my desk in 
my room which is literally three feet from the door. I had the door cracked 
a bit and I thought I heard something moving out in the hallway like 
someone was walking. I thought it was just my cats and went on with my 
business. Then I hear it again and look over to see my sister peering at me 
through the crack in the door whispering something I couldn't understand. 
She was staring right at me and I just about pissed my pants. I sat there 
and watched her to see if this was a prank or not, but she eventually 
walked back to her room and back to sleep like nothing had happened. The 
next morning I told her about it and she didn't recall anything, said she 
hadn't even dreamt about doing something like that.
Long story short, I'm closing my door after 10 pm.﻿

comments.text:
They say they help you see in the dark because the vitamin in them that's 
good for eyesight is actually helpful to night vision- it doesn't 'help you 
see in the dark' per say, but in undeveloped parts of the world that don't 
get that vitamin, the ones lacking it for so long (mostly children) find 
their eyes start to deteriorate. They don't completely, like, melt out or 
something, but something makes them look weird (forget what) and they 
develop something called 'night blindness'- a condition where your eyes 
lack that certain vitamin, causing your eyesight to decrease somewhat but 
/completely eliminates/ your vision in the dark, literally just making you 
blind at night or in a room that isn't well lit. Your eyes are simply 
unable to adjust. However the children with even the worst stages of night 
blindness, when injected with the vitamin in a large, concentrated dose, 
found their eyes restored in a couple days, a few rare cases even 
overnight. So basically it doesn't give you night vision but the vitamin 
prevents night /blindness/

top_comment.text: There is artificial chemicals in candy thats the problem not the sugar﻿
top_comment.author: Taylor Banks

comments.text:
While I don't have any candy around right now to analyze, let's take a look 
at a bottle of Coca-Cola Life, Coke being a common drink that parents 
believe gets their kids hyped.

It contains: Carbonated water, sugar, caramel color E150d, natural 
flavoring, caffeine, acidity regulator E338 and finally sweetener.

Let's take an individual look at each component. Carbonated water is a 
simple one, it's just regular water that has carbon dioxide in it, you 
exhale carbon dioxide, so nothing strange there. Sugar is a 
self-explanatory one, it's usually harvested from a type of plant. The 
caramel coloring used here, E150d, comes from a process called 
"caramelization" where you heat carbohydrates, this may sound suspicious, 
but carbohydrates comes from sugar. Try heating a few spoons of loose sugar 
in a pot and sure enough, it'll turn into a thick brown sauce. As for the 
natural flavorings, I can unfortunately not find any information on this, 
moving on. Caffeine comes from kola nuts and coffee beans, the former which 
is used in Coke. The acidity regulator used, E338, is phosphoric acid, and 
like with the "natural flavorings" used in Coke, I can't find any 
information on where this comes from. It's corrosive, however, so you may 
have a point about unnatural chemicals here. Finally, the sweetener. In the 
bottle of Coke I have, they used steviol glycosides, which, like sugar and 
caffeine, comes from a type of plant. However, most bottles (or cans) of 
Coke has no other sweetener other than sugar.

So there you go, my completely pointless comment and analysis of what a 
bottle of Coke contains. As you can see all of the ingredients except for a 
couple are all natural. However, phosphoric acid is a bit concerning and 
it's strange that the formula for their "natural flavorings" is secret. 
That being said, have a good day!
comments.author: toshineon

captions.text:
• From myths about long-dead painters to
how long you're supposed to wait after eating

in order to go for a swim, we count 15 things
you generally assume are fact, but simply

aren't so
15 - Octopus,

• You might be under the impression an octopus
has 8 legs because of the latin prefix "octo",

when in reality they only have 2
• Their back two are used to propel themselves

along the seafloor, while the remaining 6
tentacles are used for feeding, officially

classified as arms
• It's generally known in the field of marine

biology that an octopus is now known as a
two-legged, six armed animal - but since the

name has been around for so long and become
iconic, it'd be silly to try and change it

14 - Chameleon,
• Most believe a chameleon will change colour

to blend into their surroundings for camouflage,
but this generally isn't true

• The original purpose of the colour change
was for social reasons - they turn dark when

angered, and light when trying to impress
females

• A select few species of chameleon will
indeed use colour for camouflage, like the

Smith's dwarf chameleon that disguises itself
if threatened by a bird or snake, but for

the most part, chameleons only change colour
based on emotion

13 - Van Gogh,
• It's generally established that Vincent

Van Gogh cut off his own ear, when in reality
only his left earlobe had been sliced off

• Even further is the possibility his French
artists friend Paul Gauguin, also an expert

fencer, might've cut it off after a fight
- but there also exist evidence Van Gogh had

simply suffered a mental breakdown and done
it himself

• Not long after the incident, Van Gogh
sent the earlobe to a prostitute alongside

a nice letter - the perfect gift
12 - Sleepwalker,

• Never wake someone who is sleepwalking,
that's always been the golden rule - but it's

completely false
• Someone who sleepwalks is in a slow wave

sleep stage of low consciousness who performs
simple, repetitive tasks like walking to the

bathroom, cleaning around or cooking something
• It might CONFUSE the person if you wake

them up, but you're better off doing that
before they hurt themselves - although it

might be just as easy simply guiding them
back to bed, there's no right or wrong answer

11 - Lions,
• Lions are always considered "king of the

jungle", but most of them don't even LIVE
in the jungle - you'll actually find them

prowling the plains of Africa
• Ferocious wild animals at the top of the

food chain were typically referred to as 'jungle
animals' simply to distinguish them from common

farm animals
• The only lions you'll find in the jungle

will be those in the forests of India, but
even then they're a small population

10 - Brain,
• It's an age-old urban legend about how

we humans only use 10% of our brain, but the
rest can be unlocked through hard work or

drugs
• Completely false - it's a myth that arose

during the early 20th century from newly-discovered
neurological research based on misunderstandings

and misrepresentation
• There have been countless demonstrations

of neurological activity and how every part
of the brain can be active based on our activities

• In fact, if we had evolved brains with
such a tiny efficiency rate, natural selection

would've eliminated redundant brains of our
size a long time ago

9 - Mayflies,
• Most claim the mayfly only lives for one

day, and some use them as an example of how
to be time efficient when it comes to us and

getting stuff done
• In reality, most mayflies live anywhere

from between minutes and an entire week, and
that's only one part of their life cycle - months

to years spent as an aquatic nymph swimming
around waiting to grow some wings

• They'll typically hatch in a giant population
all together, dance around and mate continuously,

some witnessed as a tourist attraction or
even as a delicacy

8 - Swim Eating,
• Your parents likely always told you, wait

from between 30 mins to an hour before you
go swimming after you eat food or you'll get

stomach cramps
• Unless you're planning to go swimming

for an Olympic medal, this isn't true - you
can eat as much as you want and go swimming

anytime
• Just don't consume tons of alcohol and

go swimming - a lot of people have drowned
that way

7 - Hair & Fingernails,
• The only things that grow on a human being

after they die are the hair and fingernails
- right? NOPE.

• They require living cells in hair follicles
and fingernail beds in order to grow, and

the cells responsible die along with the rest
of the body

• The only reason this myth has been around
is because dead tissue dries out and shrinks,

protruding from follicles and fingers giving
off the ILLUSION of growth when in reality

it's simply the first stage of decomposition
6 - Keyboard keys,

• When people think about keyboards, they
generally assume the letters aren't lined

up in alphabetic order simply to encourage
more efficient typing

• But the opposite is true - the QWERTY
system was originally designed for typewriters

placing letters too-frequently used far apart
so the typewriter wouldn't jam

• A lot of alternative, less cumbersome
keyboard designs have come up, but since QWERTY

is so established in culture and society - you'd
be a fool to try and change it now

5 - Goldfish,
• It's the old saying "you have the memory

of a goldfish", that old 3-second short term
memory myth - but there's nothing even remotely

true about this one
• Researchers have successfully taught goldfish

to push levers, play fetch or even engage
in rounds of soccers, some retaining their

memories on how to do these things as much
as a year later

• In one experiment, some goldfish were
trained to hear a sound for feeding time,

and they were then released into the sea - half
a year later, the sound played over a loudspeaker

and basically all the fish swam back to where
they were released

4 - Bats,
• People always look to bats as the prime

example of a species that adapted to blindness
by developing their own sonar system - but

they're not blind, in fact, there isn't a
single species that is

• Some, like the fruit bats, don't even
have sonar - they just use giant eyes to scout

around, and microbats use their eyes to avoid
obstacles and calculate their current height

• It's difficult to pin down when this myth
started, but it's shocking how many continue

to believe it's still fact
3 - Gum ,

• If you accidentally swallow chewing gum,
it doesn't take years for it to pass through

your system
• Research has found that although gum doesn't

get digested by your body like normal food,
the longest it'll stick around is about a

week before it appears intact inside your
feces

• On rare occasions, children who gobble
down large amounts of gum might have colon

blockage, or it sticks other objects to your
intestines like coins or sunflower seeds

• Because this myth helps deter kids from
swallowing gum, it's generally better to let

them believe this one might be true
2 - Coat,

• You're a young kid, your mother tells
you to wear a coat before you go out or you'll

catch a cold - but it doesn't work like that
• Colds are a misnomer because they are,

in fact, a virus but they just happen to appear
during winter because you stay indoors more

often and are thus more likely to come into
contact with people infected

• It's just a coincidence, but people hear
the name and always jump to an obvious conclusion

1 - Sugar
• You give a kid a bunch of lollies, and

later on they start going nuts jumping all
over the furniture, breaking plates, jumping

off balconies - it's a not a sugar rush
• Based on a wide variety of experiments,

researchers found that kids who regularly
consume large doses of sugar are no more spaz

than kids who survive on a sugar-free diet
• The reason they might get excited is because

of the situation or company they're in, not
because of how many sweets they've gobbled
down

title: 15 Facts You Thought Were True -- But Aren't
